item.title: No Man‚Äôs Sky Dev Responds to Once Human Reportedly Stealing Assets
item.content:encoded:
No Man‚Äôs Sky creator has recently responded to Once Human, allegedly using their assets in a premium loot box, stating, ‚Äújokes on them.‚Äù

Hello Games No Man‚Äôs Sky was released all the way back in 2016, but has still been going strong almost a decade later. The developers recently released a brand-new update for the title, introducing improved shipbuilding, space wrecks, salvaging, and more. Once Human, on the other hand, is a more recent title, releasing in 2024. However, Once Human was recently accused of ripping off assets from No Man‚Äôs Sky, and the founder has responded.

No Man‚Äôs Sky Founder Says ‚ÄòJokes on Them‚Äô in Response to Once Human Allegedly Ripping Off Assets

Spotted by GamesRadar+, a post on the r/NoMansSkyTheGame subreddit talks about Once Human picking assets off No Man‚Äôs Sky. The user has revealed that Once Human‚Äôs cosmetic item, Sky King, looks very similar to No Man‚Äôs Sky‚Äôs Teleport Module. The item from Once Human can only be obtained as the highest-tier reward from a premium lootbox, whereas in No Man‚Äôs Sky, you can acquire the item just by progressing through the game.

The post caught the attention of Hello Games founder Sean Murray, who responded on X (formerly Twitter). Murray stated, ‚Äújokes on them ‚Äì we forgot to LOD those rivets,‚Äù with an image of the asset in question. For those wondering, LOD stands for Level of Detail, a process in game development that optimises performance by displaying simpler versions of 3D models when they are far from the camera.

In other news, Once Human received a Palworld crossover back in October. What are your thoughts on the No Man‚Äôs Sky boss‚Äôs response to Once Human reportedly stealing assets? Leave your thoughts down in the comments, and join the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more information from Insider Gaming, read about Palworld developer talking about the possibility of a story game in the future. Don‚Äôt forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 Sets Record as 2025‚Äôs Best Third-Party Xbox Game Pass Release
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft has announced that Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 has set the record as the best third-party title to release on Xbox Game Pass in 2025, adding a further accolade to Sandfall Interactive‚Äôs debut title.

Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is widely regarded to be one of the best games to release this year, with the expectation that it will sweep up numerous victories in The Game Awards next week, and the Game Pass record shows just how impressive the release of the title was.

Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is Game Pass‚Äô Best Third-Party Title of 2025

In a post on the Xbox Wire, Microsoft‚Äôs announcement of Clair Obscur‚Äôs impressive accolade detailed how it was based on the data of the number of unique players who played the title in the first 30 days of launch.

Sandfall‚Äôs creative director, Guillaume Broche, said the success was ‚Äúso far beyond what any of us could have imagined,‚Äù detailing how nerve-wracking it was to release a title, but the ‚Äúsupport of everyone has really made everything feel like a dream.‚Äù

Broche also thanked Xbox and Game Pass for their support, noting that the game‚Äôs addition to the service allows people to ‚Äútry our game when they might not have before,‚Äù particularly as the turn-based RPG genre can be off-putting for newcomers.

Clair Obscur is up for several major honors at The Game Awards, having been nominated for Game of the Year, Best Game Direction, Best Narrative, Best Art Direction, Best Score/Music, Best Audio Design, Best Independent Game, Besty Debut Indie Game, and Best Role-Playing Game, while Charlie Cox, Jennifer English, and Ben Starr make up half of the contenders for Best Performance.

Will Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 sweep all the honors at The Game Awards? Share your thoughts in the Insider Gaming Discord.

For more news, check out a Palworld dev addressing the possibility of a story-based game, and read about the latest layoffs at Eidos-Montreal.

item.title: To The Moon Founder Promises To ‚ÄòMake It Better‚Äô For 2026 Following Disastrous Expo
item.content:encoded:
To The Moon‚Äôs inaugural event took place last month in the United Kingdom, and it was, by all accounts, a complete shambles. The images and clips shared on social media painted a picture of a sorry affair in every respect, and many creators made videos exposing the event as an utter failure.

Weeks after the event, To The Moon‚Äôs founder, Monty Stewart, has surfaced on LinkedIn with a lengthy statement about what comes next for the expo. He stressed that it will be back, and suggested that this year‚Äôs expo wasn‚Äôt all that bad.

To The Moon Will Return in 2026

Early in November, To The Moon was on a little marketing kick, and the materials provided suggested that it planned to revive the UK‚Äôs failing gaming expo scene. Fast forward to a weekday in the middle of November, and To The Moon had arrived, halted temporarily by bad weather, poor planning, and an almost empty conference hall in Birmingham, England.

On social media, creators wasted no time sharing images of the event, with some claiming they‚Äôd spent hundreds to reach the venue and were left feeling extremely sour and disappointed:

There was almost nothing good to take away from To The Moon, but that‚Äôs not how the expo‚Äôs founder, Monty Stewart, put it on LinkedIn in a recent post:

On a personal level I wanted to say thank you to every single person that has supported and continues to support the vision of To The Moon Expo and attended. Every speaker, exhibitor, attendee and the like.

Seeing the vast majority of posts on LinkedIn being positive, hearing that some of our indies acquired investment meetings and received invaluable feedback on their games is a check box for me; alongside gamers being able to interact with actual games and their favourite IP‚Äôs, not just merch stalls. And let us not forget, we were the largest gathering of unique studios and games under one roof nationally within the UK for 2025.

If we can help people realise their dreams, acquire the funding they need to shoot for the stars and follow their creative passion; that is a win.

Were there some learning curves? For sure. Definitely some curveballs with the weather and a couple other aspects, but we continued onwards and adapted with the hand we were dealt.

Can we make it better? Damn right. How are we going to do that? We are looking to 2026 and moving forward with experience that only progress can teach!

I cannot wait to share with you what is coming for next year. I am also incredibly grateful to not have to handle the mantle by myself moving forward into 2026.

Innovation has always belonged those willing to challenge the status quo, not those who cling to it. So to the certain few people who have spent more energy on blocking new ideas than building their own; don‚Äôt worry, we aren‚Äôt here to replace you. Time will handle that for us.

We will continue to stand at the Vanguard for our creative industry and our movement to ensure that exhibiting at events is not fiscally gatekept and that creative passion within the UK and the globe can thrive.

Not only does Stewart think the event wasn‚Äôt all that bad, but he also intends to come back in 2026 with a new expo, seemingly expecting it to be better received just because he promises it will be.

Some reports came in ahead of the event that revealed how ill-planned it was, even before it landed:

Everyday gamers went to the expo at the NEC in Birmingham expecting a spectacle of an event because of bold marketing claims, but were met with almost nothing to do. One user wrote on X (formerly Twitter), ‚ÄòWent to see the To the Moon expo today as it was my first ever time heading to see one, it‚Äôs just disappointing how little there was to do there, legitimately one area just has consoles connected to monitors with Minecraft installed.‚Äô

This is a little first-person perspective, but I was invited to attend To The Moon and got cold feet in the morning before making the 2.5-hour drive to Birmingham, instructing my colleague to ‚Äòstay in bed‚Äô because I had some ill juju about the expo. Was that a lucky escape?

Sadly, as EGX has died a death, Insomnia appears to be coming back under some distrustful banner, and WASD has also faded into an abyss; there‚Äôs effectively nothing left in the United Kingdom for gamers.

Let us know on the Insider Gaming Discord if you attended To The Moon and what you thought about the event.

For more Insider Gaming coverage, check out the news that TheBurntPeanut lashed out at Dr Disrespect fans on stream

item.title: Elden Ring Nightreign DLC Release Times‚ÄîAll The Forsaken Hollows Start Times
item.content:encoded:
It‚Äôs another huge whammy of Elden Ring Nightreign content as The Forsaken Hollows takes night-dwelling explorers into new realms of difficulty and discovery. The Elden Ring Nightreign DLC start times are essential for those seeking fresh challenges.

The Forsaken Hollows DLC is the first full content for Nightreign. Updates have been supplied since day one, but The Forsaken Hollows adds new characters, a fresh Shifting Earth, and more.

If more hell and hellacious boss battles sound like your cup of tea, then read on for Elden Ring Nightreign‚Äôs The Forsaken Hollows DLC start times.

What Time Does Elden Ring Nightreign The Forsaken Hollows DLC Start?

Elden Ring Nightreign‚Äôs The Forsaken Hollows DLC first goes live at 3 PM PST on December 3 for PC players, and then at 9 PM for console players.

Yes, there are unique dual-start times for every region across PC and consoles‚ÄîPlayStation and Xbox. If you need a full breakdown of a more specific region, Insider Gaming has been able to track down an extensive list of start times, regions, and on which platform they fall.

All Elden Ring Nightreign DLC Release Times

The global release times for Elden Ring Nightreign‚Äôs DLC include PST, CST, GMT, AST, and many more.

Here‚Äôs the promised full list of global start times and time zones.

Are you getting Elden Ring Nightreign The Forsaken Hollows immediately? Does it look worth the price of admission? Let everyone know through the Insider Gaming Official Discord Server.

To kill some time, make sure you know that You Can Learn About Elden Ring Lore Through A Stunning 400-Page Book.

item.title: Leaks Confirm Pok√©mon Pokopia Post-Apocalyptic Fan Theory
item.content:encoded:
Pok√©mon fans appear to have hit the nail on the head with a huge fan theory regarding Pok√©mon Pokopia, with leaks confirming the speculation.

Pok√©mon Pokopia releases on March 5, 2026, putting players in control of a playable Ditto that has transformed into a human, with the game‚Äôs setting showing islands filled with Pok√©mon but no humans in sight.

That has led to intense speculation that Pok√©mon Pokopia takes place in a post-apocalyptic world, and a fresh leak seems to confirm that environment.

Leaked Pok√©mon Pokopia Map Shows Post-Apocalyptic Kanto

Posting on X, CentroLeaks shared what is claimed to be the Pok√©mon Pokopia map, and the translation shows that a post-apocalyptic adventure through Kanto is on the cards.

Areas on the map include Fuschia, with ‚Äúdried up and unfertilized fieldland,‚Äù Pewter, ‚Äúan abandoned mine covered by rocks,‚Äù and, perhaps the most telling of them all, the Viridian Area with a ‚Äúnever-ending burning forest of ash.‚Äù

All of those areas are well known in the Kanto region, with Fuschia City being the home of the Safari Zone, Pewter City presenting the first gym badge test against Brock, and Viridian Forest being one of the first areas players explore in the world of Kanto.

Additional content, reportedly arriving in DLC or as part of post-launch updates, includes areas for Cerulean, Cinnibar, Lavender, and Celedon.

Ever since the first trailer of Pok√©mon Pokopia appeared, fans have theorized that the game‚Äôs setting would be a post-apocalptic version of Kanto, with major hints including a destroyed first-generation Pok√©dex and the remnants of buildings like Pok√©mon Centers.

Fans have also theorised that Peakychu, the mysterious ghost-like version of Pikachu, is the deceased version of Red‚Äôs partner Pok√©mon Pokopia, and Mosslax, a Snorlax covered in greenery, is the same Snorlax that players in the Kanto region are tasked with waking up by using the Pok√©flute.

It remains to be seen whether those theories are true, and it could be that Pok√©mon Pokopia takes place in an alternate universe away from the main franchise.

While this may seem far-fetched, Pok√©mon has blown open the doors to craziness with the likes of time-travelling in Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A and wormholes in Ultra Sun & Ultra Moon.

What secrets do you think Pok√©mon Pokopia has in store? Share your theories in the Insider Gaming Discord.

For more Pok√©mon, check out the secret rare cards revealed for the Ascended Heroes TCG set, and take a look at how the franchise is breaking the level 100 cap for the first time.
